pageData.text: The respiratory system provides the means for the intake of oxygen and the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide, a byproduct of cell metabolism, in the bloodstream. Air travels down the <button className='glossary-text'>trachea</button>, which branches to form two <button className='glossary-text'>bronchi</button>. Each bronchus enters a lung. Bronchi further branch into <button className='glossary-text'>bronchioles</button>, which branch even further into <button className='glossary-text'>alveoli</button>. Alveoli are the sites of gas exchange. The walls of alveoli throughout the lungs are the interface of blood and air. Alveoli have moist epithelium that contain a dense net of capillaries. Gases are exchanged across the membranes of the capillaries and alveolar walls.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes
Activity 1: Trachea Tissue Types – 25 minutes
Activity 2: Lung Tissue Types – 15 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.title: Overview Video: Introduction to Histology: Respiratory System

text: Recognize and describe the different tissue types present in the respiratory and conductive zones of the respiratory system.
Compare and contrast the different epithelial tissue types in the various parts of the airways.
Associate the structures of the respiratory system with the surrounding tissues and describe their functions.

pageData.text: Medical dramas have gained in popularity in the last few decades. Although characters in these dramas often work in fast-paced emergency rooms, sometimes they find themselves in public situations where they are urged to perform emergency medical procedures with minimal equipment. One of the most common of these medical procedures is the tracheotomy.

A tracheotomy is a procedure in which an incision is made in the windpipe to relieve an obstruction to breathing (i.e., suffocation, inflammation, tumors). Once the incision is made, a tracheal tube is placed inside it and an individual can breathe without needing air to flow through the nose or mouth. On television, this procedure is often performed with an everyday object, such as a ballpoint pen. The pen is used to both access the windpipe and act as the tracheal tube. Although this technique can work in an emergency, it should be considered a last resort and only be performed by a real-life medical professional.

pageData.altText:
Figure A shows a cross section of the human head and neck after a tracheotomy procedure with major respiratory passageways and tracheostomy tube labeled.
Figure B shows the bust of a patient lying down with a tracheostomy tube held in place by a strap around the patient's neck.

pageData.text: The respiratory system is responsible for gas exchange—the inhalation of oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and the exhalation of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>). The lungs, conducting airways, and the diaphragm are key structures of the system.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Respiratory System

pageData.subTitle: Lungs and Diaphragm
pageData.text: Human lungs are sponge-like organs found in the thoracic (chest) cavity. The right lung has 3 lobes and is larger than the bilobed left lung, as the heart occupies more space on the left side. The diaphragm is a domed, sheet-like muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

pageData.subTitle: Breathing
pageData.text:
During inhalation, the diaphragm contracts, and air is pulled through the conducting airways into the lungs.
During exhalation, the diaphragm relaxes, and air is pushed from the lungs.

pageData.subTitle: Bronchi, Bronchioles, and Alveoli
pageData.text: Air enters the lungs from the trachea through the right and left bronchus. These branching airways lead to bronchioles and end in microscopic air sacs called alveoli. The alveoli are the sites of gas exchange between the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.

The respiratory system is responsible for allowing the diffusion of oxygen into the blood stream and carbon dioxide out of the blood stream. This gas exchange takes place in the lungs in specialized structures called the . The respiratory system (Figure 1) is anatomically divided into two parts: an (including the , , , , and ) and a (including the , , and alveoli).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Graphic representation of a torso of a human body showing the respiratory system, including the nose, ethmoid sinuses, tongue, pharynx, trachea, bronchus, and bronchioles. The inset to the right shows a detail of a lung with the bronchioles and alveoli.

pageData.text: The respiratory system is functionally divided into two zones with different functions. The <button className='glossary-text'>conducting zone</button> brings the air into and out of the body, and the <button className='glossary-text'>respiratory zone</button> is where gas exchange takes place. In order to facilitate the intake of oxygen from the air, the incoming air is moistened and warmed up in the nose and sinuses. The nose and sinuses also filter out contaminants from the air and traps them in mucus that is secreted by specialized cells within the nasal cavity. To allow for unrestricted airflow into the respiratory zone, the parts that make up the conducting zone need to be held open at all times. In order to achieve this, <button className='glossary-text'>hyaline cartilage</button> is present in the passageways in rings instead of a solid layer. You can clearly see this in the trachea and bronchi (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Cartoon-style drawing of a human trachea showing cartilage rings and bronchi.

pageData.question: Which of the following sets of structures are included in the lower respiratory tract?

options.text: nasal cavity, sinuses, pharynx, larynx, and trachea
nasal cavity, sinuses, pharynx, and alveoli

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The respiratory system is anatomically divided into two parts: an upper respiratory tract (including the nasal cavity, sinuses, pharynx, larynx, and trachea) and a lower respiratory tract (including the bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli).

pageData.question: Which of the following structures is part of both the lower respiratory tract and the conducting zone of the respiratory system?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The bronchioles belong to the lower respiratory tract anatomically, but they belong to the conducting zone functionally.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The respiratory system is responsible for allowing the diffusion of oxygen into the blood stream and carbon dioxide out of the blood stream. This gas exchange takes place in the lungs in specialized structures called the alveoli. The respiratory system is anatomically divided into two parts: an upper respiratory tract and a lower respiratory tract, with the trachea and its superior structures in the upper tract and the bronchi and its inferior structures in the lower tract.

img.alt: Figure 1: Graphic representation of a torso of a human body showing the respiratory system, including the nose, ethmoid sinuses, tongue, pharynx, trachea, bronchus, and bronchioles. The inset to the right shows a detail of a lung with the bronchioles and alveoli.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The respiratory system is functionally divided into two zones with different functions. The conducting zone brings the air into and out of the body, and the respiratory zone is where gas exchange takes place. In order to facilitate the intake of oxygen from the air, the incoming air is moistened and warmed up in the nose and sinuses.

pageData.text: The <button className='glossary-text'>trachea</button> is made up of several distinct tissue layers. The inner layer consists mainly of <button className='glossary-text'>pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelia</button> tissue. This epithelium has small hair-like structures, <button className='glossary-text'>cilia</button> which can transport the mucus along. Under this layer of epithelial cells is a layer of loose connective tissue called <button className='glossary-text'>lamina propria</button>. This lamina propria is present throughout the respiratory system. The layer of pseudostratified ciliated epithelial tissue and the lamina propria together form the <button className='glossary-text'>tracheal mucosa</button> (Figure 3).

Underneath the tracheal mucosa sits the <button className='glossary-text'>submucosa</button> layer (Figure 4). This layer is made up of fibrous connective tissue. This tissue looks similar to the loose connective tissue from the mucosa, making the transition between these two layers sometimes hard to spot. The submucosa also contains <button className='glossary-text'>glands</button>, which are the <button className='glossary-text'>goblet cells</button> that produce the mucus necessary to moisten and lubricate the airway and trap foreign particles.

pageData.desc: An image of a tissue sample showing the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium (an upper line of light-purple rectangular cells and irregular purple blobs in them with a yellow top border) layered over the laminar propria (light-blue lines with small purple blobs in them).
pageData.altText: Figure 3: An image of a tissue sample showing the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium (an upper line of light-purple rectangular cells and irregular purple blobs in them with a yellow top border) layered over the laminar propria (light-blue lines with small purple blobs in them).

pageData.desc: An image showing purple tissue with light-pink on top (the mucosa) and darker pink on the bottom (the submucosa).
pageData.altText: Figure 4: An image showing purple tissue with light-pink on top (the mucosa) and darker pink on the bottom (the submucosa).

pageData.question: What are the hair-like structures found on the surface of the inner layer of the trachea?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This epithelium has small hair-like structures called cilia.

pageData.question: The inner layer of the trachea is made up of mainly pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelia tissue. What is the role of the cilia on the surface of this layer?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This function of cilia on the epithelium is to move mucus.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To allow for unrestricted airflow into the respiratory zone, the parts that make up the conducting zone need to be held open at all times. In order to achieve this, hyaline cartilage is present in the passageways in rings instead of a solid layer. The trachea is made up of several distinct tissue layers. The inner layer consists mainly of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelia tissue. This epithelium has small hair-like structures, which transport mucus along. Under this layer of epithelial cells is a layer of loose connective tissue called lamina propria. This lamina propria is present throughout the respiratory system. The layer of pseudostratified ciliated epithelial tissue and the lamina propria together form the tracheal mucosa.

img.alt: Figure 3: An image of a tissue sample showing the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium (an upper line of light-purple rectangular cells and irregular purple blobs in them with a yellow top border) layered over the laminar propria (light-blue lines with small purple blobs in them).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To allow for unrestricted airflow into the respiratory zone, the parts that make up the conducting zone need to be held open at all times. In order to achieve this, hyaline cartilage is present in the passageways in rings instead of a solid layer. The trachea is made up of several distinct tissue layers. The inner layer consists mainly of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelia tissue. This epithelium has small hair-like structures, which transport mucus along. Under this layer of epithelial cells is a layer of loose connective tissue called lamina propria. This lamina propria is present throughout the respiratory system. The layer of pseudostratified ciliated epithelial tissue and the lamina propria together form the tracheal mucosa.

img.alt: Figure 3: An image of a tissue sample showing the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium (an upper line of light-purple rectangular cells and irregular purple blobs in them with a yellow top border) layered over the laminar propria (light-blue lines with small purple blobs in them).

pageData.text: The splits into two main (), one for each lung. These bronchi split multiple times until reaching the terminal , which contain simple cuboidal epithelium. These then split up further into respiratory bronchioles which end in the . Only the respiratory bronchioles and the alveoli are part of the of the respiratory system. The respiratory bronchiole (Figure 5) is made up of cuboidal epithelial cells. Each bronchiole will transition into an . Around this duct are clusters of alveoli which are called . At the start of the alveolar duct sits a ring of smooth muscle, which allows for opening and closing of the specific duct.

The respiratory, or gas exchange, portion can be characterized by the alveoli, which are epithelia tissues formed into small sacs that increase the surface area and facilitate gas exchange. The fact that these alveoli have a sac-like appearance leads to the overall spongy consistency of the lungs. In both lungs together, there are approximately 300 million alveoli present.

Throughout the respiratory portion, arteries can clearly be seen. These arteries will split up into capillaries, which surround the alveoli. The thin cell layers of both the alveoli and the capillaries allow for efficient gas exchange to take place at the <button className='glossary-text'>respiratory membrane</button>.

pageData.desc: An image showing bronchioles and alveoli, which look like thin, pink strands with purple circles in them forming irregular-shaped compartments. In the bottom center of one of these compartments is close to being circular (smooth muscle) with a pink, almost circular, shape in it (pulmonary artery).
pageData.altText: Figure 5: An image showing bronchioles and alveoli, which look like thin, pink strands with purple circles in them forming irregular-shaped compartments. In the bottom center of one of these compartments is close to being circular (smooth muscle) with a pink, almost circular, shape in it (pulmonary artery).

pageData.text: Oxygen-poor blood passes through the capillaries of the <button className='glossary-text'>alveoli</button>. Carbon dioxide passes into the alveoli through the <button className='glossary-text'>respiratory membrane</button> while oxygen passes back out and leaves the capillaries as oxygen-rich blood (Figure 6). Within the alveoli there are also <button className='glossary-text'>Type I</button> and <button className='glossary-text'>Type II alveolar cells</button>. Type I cells are the squamous epithelial cells that alveoli walls are composed of that are surrounded by a very thin membrane. Type II cells excrete a fluid with surfactant which supply a coating for the surfaces of the alveoli. Alveoli also contain many <button className='glossary-text'>alveolar macrophages</button> which clear away the air spaces within the alveoli of harmful particles that have entered the respiratory tract (Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Structure of an Alveolus

pageData.question: Which of the following structures gives the lungs an overall spongy consistency?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Alveoli have a sac-like appearance, and this leads to the overall spongy consistency of the lungs.

pageData.question: The alveoli are responsible for exchanging carbon dioxide for oxygen in the body. Which of the following structures surround the alveoli to facilitate this function?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The alveoli exchange gases with blood, which is carried by the capillaries surrounding the alveoli.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Each bronchiole will transition into an alveolar duct. Around this duct are clusters of alveoli which are called alveolar sacs. At the start of the alveolar duct sits a ring of smooth muscle, which allows for opening and closing of the specific duct. The respiratory, or gas exchange, portion can be characterized by the alveoli, which are epithelia tissues formed into small sacs that increase the surface area and facilitate gas exchange. The sac-like appearance of the alveoli gives lungs a spongy consistency. Oxygen-poor blood passes through the capillaries of the alveoli. Carbon dioxide passes into the alveoli through the respiratory membrane while oxygen passes back out and leaves the capillaries as oxygen-rich blood. Within the alveoli there are also Type I and Type II alveolar cells.

In the bottom center of one of these compartments is close to being circular (smooth muscle) with a pink, almost circular, shape in it (pulmonary artery).

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up the microscope. In Activity 1, you will place the trachea slide on the stage and focus the tissue layers in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the layers of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. Next, focus the mucosa in the field of view and record an image of the layer under ideal magnification. Then, identify the sublayers of the magnified layer. Lastly, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation and compare the characteristics of each trachea layer. In Activity 2, place the lung slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Lastly, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation and compare the characteristics of each structure.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Introduction to Histology investigation (item number 580572) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Read all the instructions for these laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activities. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following structures is part of both the lower respiratory tract and the respiratory zone?

The structures in the conducting zone must be held open at all times to facilitate the flow of air to the conducting zone. Which of the following best describes the structure of the hyaline cartilage in these structures that makes this possible?

options.text: The cartilage is in many thin layers.
The cartilage is supported by bone.
The cartilage is full of holes.
The cartilage is one solid layer.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the tissue layers of the trachea from innermost to outermost?

options.text: pseudostratified ciliated epithelium, lamina propria, submucosa
mucosa, pseudostratified ciliated epithelium, lamina propria

assestmentData.question: The overall spongy consistency of the lungs is primarily caused by the presence of which of the following?
The alveoli walls are comprised of which of the following cells?
Into which of the following items would it be appropriate to place discarded microscope slides before placing them in the household trash at the conclusion of this investigation?

options.text: No intermediate container is necessary for slides disposal.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.
Obtain all listed needed materials from your kit. (Remember: when carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.)
Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify its key parts. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100×) objective, identify it, but do not use it during this investigation.

You may be asked to draw pictures and either photograph or scan them for submission, or you may need to take pictures through the microscope using a digital camera or mobile device. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, view the following video:
In Activity 1, you will observe the tissues of the <button className='glossary-text'>trachea</button> under the microscope and compare their characteristics.
Collect the <button className='glossary-text'>trachea</button> slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Note: Remember, the label should be face up on the left.
Center and focus the slide using the lowest power.

Scan through the slide until you come across a section where you can clearly see the different layers of the trachea as mentioned in the Background section. Increase magnification as needed so you can distinguish the mucosa and <button className='glossary-text'>submucosa</button>.

pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Identify the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium and the <button className='glossary-text'>lamina propria</button>. Take or draw a picture.
Write down the answers to the following questions in Data Table 1. Also record the total magnification needed to best view the object.

text: What makes the different layers mentioned in Steps 5 and 6 stand out?
What were the main details you could observe?

pageData.text: Return to the lowest power.
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 2, you will observe the tissues of the lung under the microscope and compare their characteristics.
Collect the lung slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide in the lowest power.

Scan through the slide until you come across a section where you can clearly see the different structures of the lung tissue, as shown in <button className='resource-text'>Figure 5</button>. Increase magnification as needed to view these structures.

pageData.altText: camera symbol

Write down the answers to the following questions in Data Table 2. Record the total magnification needed to best view the objects.

text: What makes the different layers mentioned in Step 5 stand out?
What were the main details you could observe?

pageData.text: Return to the lowest power.
Replace the slide in the slide box.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up the microscope. In Activity 1, you will place the trachea slide on the stage and focus the tissue layers in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the layers of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. Next, focus the mucosa in the field of view and record an image of the layer under ideal magnification. Then, identify the sublayers of the magnified layer. In Activity 2, place the lung slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Lastly, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation and compare the characteristics of each structure.

data.title: Alveolar duct
data.content: Tiny duct that arises from each respiratory bronchiole and connects them to alveolar sacs

data.title: Alveolar macrophages
data.content: Immune system cells that clear away the air spaces within the alveoli of harmful particles that have entered the respiratory tract

data.title: Alveolar sacs
data.content: Clusters of alveoli that surround each alveolar duct

data.title: Alveoli
data.content: Epithelia tissues formed into small sacs that increase the surface area and facilitate gas exchange in the lungs

data.title: Bronchi
data.content: The two large airways that branch from the trachea

data.title: Bronchioles
data.content: Tiny passageways that branch from the bronchus in each lung

data.title: Cilia
data.content: Hair-like organelles on the surface of some cells

data.title: Conducting zone
data.content: One of two different functional zones of the respiratory system; this zone brings the air into and out of the body

data.title: Glands
data.content: A secreting group of cells

data.title: Goblet cells
data.content: Glands that produce the mucus necessary to moisten and lubricate the airway and trap foreign particles

data.title: Hyaline cartilage
data.content: The most abundant type of cartilage in the human body, and which has an extracellular matrix that contains tightly packed collagen fibers; in respiratory passageways, it is present in rings instead of a solid layer

data.title: Lamina propria
data.content: A layer of loose connective tissue present throughout the respiratory system

data.title: Larynx
data.content: The passageway composed mainly of cartilage, voluntary muscle, and vocal cords; it is used for breathing, swallowing, and talking; commonly referred to as the voicebox

data.title: Lower respiratory tract
data.content: One of two anatomical divisions of the respiratory system that includes the bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli

data.title: Nasal cavity
data.content: The cavity located above the bone that forms the roof of the mouth; it is lined with a mucus-producing, ciliated epithelium and connects to the pharynx

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The muscular passageway that connects the sinuses and nasal cavity to the trachea; commonly referred to as the throat

data.title: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelia
data.content: A type of epithelial tissue that has the appearance of stratified tissue, yet consists of a single layer of cells; it makes up the inner layer of the trachea

data.title: Respiratory membrane
data.content: The location of gas exchange in the alveoli; it consists of the alveolar and capillary walls

data.title: Respiratory zone
data.content: One of two functional zones of the respiratory system; this zone is responsible for gas exchange

data.title: Sinuses
data.content: A connected system of hollow cavities in the skull

data.title: Submucosa
data.content: The layer of fibrous connective tissue underneath the tracheal mucosa

data.title: Trachea
data.content: The passageway with C-shaped rings of cartilage that extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes; commonly referred to as the windpipe

data.title: Tracheal mucosa
data.content: The tissue layer of the trachea made up of pseudostratified ciliated epithelial tissue and the lamina propria

data.title: Type I alveolar cells
data.content: The squamous epithelial cells of which alveoli walls are composed and that are surrounded by a very thin membrane

data.title: Type II alveolar cells
data.content: The cells in the alveoli that excrete a fluid with surfactant, which supplies a coating for the surfaces of the alveoli

data.title: Upper respiratory tract
data.content: One of two anatomical divisions of the respiratory system that includes the nasal cavity, sinuses, pharynx, larynx, and trachea
